Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Volcanoes and Lakes in the Science and Culture of the Spanish Empire

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

This award is a doctoral dissertation improvement grant. It supports a study of the production, circulation, and use of knowledge about volcanoes and lakes in Guatemala and Mexico during the early modern period (sixteenth through eighteenth centuries). The focus of the study is two indigenous groups that inhabited both volcano and lake regions: the Nahua in Central Mexico and the Kaqchikel Maya in highland Guatemala. The investigator will use ethno-historical methods to evaluate archival documents, travel accounts, natural historical treatises, and Spanish chronicles, as well as visual materials including indigenous codices, cartographies and maps, and engravings. An analysis of these materials will facilitate a reconstruction of the variety and circulation of interpretations regarding volcanoes and lakes, and thereby situate nascent volcanology and the methods of empirical observation among indigenous groups and Spanish explorers in the sixteenth century and beyond. The results of this project will be shared at conferences on environmental history and published in professional journals. Transcriptions and translations of certain documents will also be published. More broadly, the results of this project may provide useful information for contemporary volcanology, a "slow science," meaning one that draws from extended periods of observations and historical information to understand the present. The investigator plans to engage with volcanologists in Mexico and Guatemala to help strengthen exchanges between volcanologists and historians. Capturing the efficacy of indigenous knowledge may also contribute to indigenous revitalization efforts.

Technical Summary

This project is significant for several reasons. It focuses on volcanoes and lakes in Mexico and Guatemala, which represent an understudied area in environmental history and history of science/STS studies. It grapples with the problem of historical erasure of indigenous epistemologies in the early modern period by emphasizing indigenous knowledge and cosmology in the study of lakes and volcanoes. In doing so, it contributes to STS debates about tensions between "western" science and localized indigenous knowledge. This project also evaluates the implications of hybridity and translation in cultural exchanges to push beyond the indigenous/western dichotomy in scientific development. The project will also serve to increase our understanding of how people engaged with volcanic and lacustrine terrain and lived in potentially unstable landscapes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Science, Technology, and Society Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant supported the completion of research for a history of science dissertation titled "Explosive Encounters: Volcanic Landscapes, Indigenous Knowledge, and Cultural Exchange in Early Modern Mesoamerica." Broadly, this project evaluated how historical human populations living in the proximity of active volcanoes interacted with their built and natural environments. The research focused on three historically (and currently) active volcanoes: Popocatepetl in central Mexico, and Fuego and Pacaya in highland Guatemala, which almost constantly spouted ash and had large eruptions in 1665, 1717, and 1775, respectively. Spanning the years 1519-1780, the project evaluates how the Nahua, Kaqchikel Maya, and Spanish populations living at the base of these landforms produced and circulated knowledge about volcanic topography, ash fall, and eruptions and navigated seismic risks. By focusing on a pre-volcanology period, this research advances the role of Indigenous knowledge, local observation, and nascent earth science as these early modern individuals sought to make sense of their turbulent natural worlds.

Under the supervision of the PI, the co-PI carried out the research for this project during a six-month period in archives and libraries in Mexico City and Puebla, Mexico. This built on twelve months of previous archival research in Guatemala, Spain, and the US that resulted in the collection of documents about the volcanoes and local populations during periods of dormancy and eruptions. In Mexico, the co-PI worked in seven different archives and libraries to consult, collect, and analyze documents from over 150 archive boxes/volumes. These primarily contained information about Popocatepetl during periods of light ash fall and eruptions, as well as records from the Nahuas towns surrounding the volcano, including Amecameca, Atlixco, San Andres Calpan, Tetela del Volcan, and Huaquechula, among others. The co-PI also made field visits to Atlixco, Huaquechula, and Tetela de Volcan to gain a deeper understanding of the region. From Tetela, the co-PI traveled with other researchers, including volcanologists, archaeologists, and anthropologists, to smaller towns high on Popocatepetl's slopes to learn more about the current economic activities in this area, the types of building methods, and about the daily livelihood of people living in seismically-prone areas.

The research revealed that early modern Indigenous populations and Spaniards possessed distinct interpretations of a volcano's ecology, which shaped how they constructed their homes in the volcano's shadow and responded to eruptions. The dissertation argues that the inherent drama and inexplicability of volcanic activity pushed local Spanish populations initially to rely on Indigenous knowledge and rethink their perceptions of nature. This dissertation follows the epistemological shifts that occurred among local inhabitants as they sought to balance between the creative and destructive potentials of these landforms. Although local populations continued to inhabit the areas surrounding Popocatepetl following the eruption, individuals in Guatemala began to doubt their ability to live safely near Fuego and Pacaya after they erupted. Ultimately, this culminated in the relocation of the Guatemala's capital city as a means of managing the destructive potential of the surrounding lands.

Preliminary results from this dissertation research have been presented at public talks, conferences, libraries, and workshops. The primary byproduct of the research will be a doctoral dissertation and subsequent book manuscript that advance our knowledge about early modern volcanoes. This remains relevant in today's context, since all three volcanoes are active, especially Fuego, which experienced its strongest eruption in over fifty years last June (2018). Since volcanology partially draws on information collected from extensive periods of observation and historical information, this research deepens our familiarity with eruptive patterns, along with the benefits and risks that volcanoes pose to local populations. Finally, it captures the efficacy of Indigenous knowledge in early modern interpretations about these landforms. Ultimately, this project transforms our shared histories with the earth, to remind us of the potency of the natural world in the dynamics of colonization and cultural survival.
